title: Type B Aortic Dissection
diagnosis_topic: Acute Type B Aortic Dissection — Medical vs. Endovascular Repair
setup_script: A 55-year-old man with poorly controlled hypertension presents with sudden sharp chest and back pain. He is diaphoretic but alert. He has no history of Marfan syndrome or prior aortic disease. On exam, his pulses are asymmetric. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 180/110 mmHg, HR 100 bpm, RR 20/min, Temp 36.9 °C.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs focused physical exam
dynamic_flow.reply: Unequal blood pressures in arms, decreased right femoral pulse, neurologic exam intact.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders ECG and troponin

dynamic_flow.reply: CT angiography shows Stanford type B dissection starting distal to the left subclavian artery extending to renal arteries; no rupture or malperfusion.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates blood pressure control promptly
dynamic_flow.reply: IV beta-blocker given, systolic BP lowered <120 mmHg, patient’s pain improves.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays blood pressure control
dynamic_flow.reply: Dissection propagates, patient develops oliguria and rising creatinine.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults vascular surgery early
dynamic_flow.reply: Discussion regarding indications for TEVAR vs. medical management.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about TEVAR indications
dynamic_flow.reply: Indicated if malperfusion, rupture, uncontrolled hypertension, or rapid expansion.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident manages with antihypertensives only
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient stabilizes, pain controlled, renal function preserved.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about pain control
dynamic_flow.reply: IV opioids provided, pain decreases, sympathetic tone reduced.
Assessment includes renal perfusion, bowel ischemia, lower extremity pulses, spinal cord function.
Patient develops worsening abdominal pain and lactic acidosis suggesting mesenteric ischemia.
Surveillance plan includes CTA at 3, 6, and 12 months, then annually.
Counseling provided on strict lifelong blood pressure control and adherence to imaging follow-up.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of aortic dissection symptoms and development of appropriate differential.
Timely initiation of imaging and antihypertensive therapy.
Determining when TEVAR is indicated versus when medical management suffices.
Monitoring for complications including malperfusion syndromes.
Providing appropriate patient education and surveillance planning.
